metadata.case_name: Maulana Abdul Shakoor v. Rikhab Chand Jain

facts.text: Appellant Maulana Abdul Shakoor elected to Council of States by Electoral College of Ajmer (30 members State Legislature); received 19 votes against 7 for respondent No. 1 Rikhab Chand Jain; total valid votes 26, 3 invalid.
Result published in Official Gazette on March 31, 1956 declaring appellant elected.
Notification issued February 17, 1956: nominations February 28 to March 1, 1956; scrutiny March 5, 1956; polling March 22, 1956.
Appellant filed two nomination papers on February 28, 1956, and third on March 1, 1956.
Respondent Rikhab Chand Jain filed nomination papers on March 1, 1956.
On March 5, 1956, respondent raised objections to appellant's nominations, main ground: appellant holding office of profit under Government.

Returning Officer on March 6, 1956 rejected two nomination papers of February 28, 1956 (under Durgah Khwaja Saheb Emergency Provisions Act, 1950 in force till February 29, 1956) but accepted third of March 1, 1956 (under Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 coming into force March 1, 1956).

Respondent filed election petition on May 2/3, 1956 under s. 81 Representation of the People Act, 1951 alleging third nomination also invalid under Art. 102(1)(a) Constitution; prayed for declaration as elected due to thrown away votes.
Election Tribunal majority (January 31, 1957) held appellant held office of profit under Government on March 1, 1956; set aside election, declared respondent elected.
Tribunal Chairman dissented: on March 1, 1956 appellant no longer held office of profit under Government; election valid.
Tribunal unanimously held two February 28, 1956 nomination papers invalid as appellant held office of profit then.

Appellant appointed honorary mohatmin (manager) of Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari on February 28, 1955 by Administrator of Durgah Khwaja Saheb; to work under Administrator; paid Rs. 100 per month from May 1955 (salary/honorarium).
Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari: school for Persian, Arabic, Muslim theology; before 1951 managed by Government of Nizam of Hyderabad; 1951 taken over by Durgah Committee.
Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1936 (XXIII of 1936): management vested in Durgah Committee (body corporate); s.11(f) power to appoint servants.

Replaced by Durgah Khwaja Saheb Emergency Provisions Act, 1950 (XVII of 1950) till February 29, 1956: Committee superseded, management vested in Administrator appointed by Central Government under control of Central Government.

Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 (XXXVI of 1955): assent October 14, 1955, force from March 1, 1956; s.4: administration vested in Committee (body corporate, 5-9 Hanafi Muslims appointed by Central Government); s.8 Government power to supersede; s.9 Nazim (administrator, ex-officio secretary) appointed by Government in consultation with Committee, salary from Durgah funds; s.11(i) Committee power to appoint/suspend/dismiss servants; s.20 bye-laws for duties/powers of employees, Government may cancel bye-laws.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government of India on March 1, 1956, attracting disqualification under Art. 102(1)(a) of the Constitution for the nomination paper filed that day.
Whether the appointment as mohatmin amounted to an office of profit under the Government.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appointment as manager of school neither an office nor office of profit nor under the Government; on March 1, 1956 under 1955 Act, no longer held office under Government.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955; Art. 102(1)(a) Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Raised three construction questions: not office, not of profit, not under Government.

respondent_arguments.text: Even under 1955 Act, appellant held office of profit under Government as Committee appointed by Government, acts through Nazim appointed by Government, power of removal/supersession, bye-laws for employees controllable by Government.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 ss.4,5,6(2),8,9,11(i),20; Art. 102(1)(a)

respondent_arguments.text: Votes for appellant thrown away; declare respondent elected.
Test of power of dismissal by Government applicable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.

court_reasoning.text: Assumed office of profit; controversy whether under Government of India; Art. 102(1)(a) applies only to office under Government, unlike Arts. 58(2), 66(4) which include authorities under Government control.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difference in language between disqualification for President/VP vs. legislators.

court_reasoning.text: Committee under 1955 Act is statutory body corporate; servants not under Government merely because Committee appointed by Government, removable, makes bye-laws controllable by Government.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant not appointed/removed by Government, not paid from Government revenues.

court_reasoning.text: Tests: power of appointment/continuation/revocation by Government at discretion, payment from Government revenues; none satisfied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appointment by statutory body from endowment funds.

court_reasoning.text: Shivnandan Sharma inapplicable: not employed by Government servant paid from Government funds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Different context under Industrial Disputes Act.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide thrown away votes or other nominations as March 1 nomination valid.

holdings.text: Appellant not holding office of profit under Government of India on March 1, 1956; nomination valid; election not hit by Art. 102(1)(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule on employment by servant of master not applicable; different facts under Industrial Disputes Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification for office of profit under Government (not extended to authorities under control for legislators unlike President/VP); applied to hold no disqualification.

statutes_cited.name: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior management by Committee (body corporate) with power to appoint servants.

statutes_cited.name: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Emergency Provisions Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Superseded Committee, vested management in Administrator under Central Government control till Feb 29, 1956.

statutes_cited.name: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Vested management in Committee (body corporate appointed by Government); powers over servants; Government control limited; salary from endowment funds.

statutes_cited.name: Religious Endowments Act, 1863
statutes_cited.relevance: Pre-1936 administration by Committee constituted by Chief Commissioner.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Election Tribunal majority set aside; appellant's election upheld as nomination paper of March 1, 1956 valid and not disqualified under Art. 102(1)(a). No need to decide thrown away votes.

key_quotes.text: "Merely because the Committee or the members of the Committee are removeable by the Government of India or the Committee can make bye-laws prescribing the duties and powers of its employees cannot in our opinion convert the servants of the Committee into holders of office of profit under the Government of India."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning distinguishing statutory body servants from Government office holders.

key_quotes.text: "The power of the Government to appoint a person to an office of profit or to continue him in that office or revoke his appointment at their discretion and payment from out of Government revenues are important factors..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for 'office of profit under the Government'.
